page.title: Operational history of the Sukhoi Su-25

revision.comment: /* Ivorian Civil War */ Use of MILAN missiles is document by the reference 'Su-25 units in combat' and by the third source I gave.
revision.text:
[[File:Sukhoi Su-25, Russia - Air Force AN2192992.jpg|thumb|A [[Russian Air Force]] Su-25 in 2012. ]]
== 1980–1990 ==
=== Soviet–Afghan War === In total, the [[Sukhoi Su-25]] amassed a total of 60,000 sorties throughout its service in [[Afghanistan]] until the Soviet withdrawal in February 1989. The first combat Su-25 unit to be formed was the 200th Independent Attack Squadron (OShAE) based out of [[Sitalçay|Sital-Chai]] in [[Soviet Azerbaijan]]. The first aircraft from the unit arrived in Afghanistan in the summer of 1981, with the full unit deploying in June to [[Shindand Air Base|Shindand airfield]] in the western part of the country. The deployment was called Operation ''Exam'' and involved a team of engineers and technicians who would oversee the aircraft and evaluate its performance. The first Su-25 combat missions began on 25 July with the 200th OShAE flying counterinsurgency sorties and close air support in support of the [[5th Guards Motor Rifle Division|5th Motorized Rifle Division]]. By 1982, the Su-25's area of responsibility expanded and the aircraft began flying missions sometimes as far as [[Kabul]] with pilots flying on average 4–5, sometimes as many as 8, sorties a day. The aircraft typically flew with external fuel tanks to increase its range but was barred from flying in poor weather conditions or nighttime due to faulty navigational equipment. By the time the squadron left Afghanistan in October 1982, its Su-25s had logged more than 2,000 sorties with no losses, however some had sustained damage due to ground fire. The deployment allowed engineers to make several modifications to the aircraft's weapons systems, replacing them with ones more suited for mountain operations and installing increased countermeasures and defensive systems.<ref name="Mladeno2013">{{cite book|author=Alexander Mladenov|title=Sukhoi Su-25 Frogfoot|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mbCdCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA44|date=20 September 2013|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=978-1-4728-0478-5|pages=44–45}}</ref>
[[File:Su-25 at Le Bourget, 1989.JPEG|thumb|Soviet Su-25 Frogfoot aircraft on display at the 38th [[Paris Air Show|Paris International Air and Space Show]] in 1989.]]
The introduction of the Su-25 in Afghanistan led to a vastly expanded scope of operations by Soviet ground commanders who could now insert their troops deeper into guerrilla territory with better air cover. The [[Mujahideen]] grew to fear and respect the Su-25 as the war grew on, adapting their tactics around the assumption of its use.<ref name="Jalali2002">{{cite book|author=Ali Ahmad Jalali|title=Afghan Guerrilla Warfare: In the Words of the Mjuahideen Fighters|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3VJJDijysx8C&pg=PA227|date=18 January 2002|publisher=MBI Publishing Company|isbn=978-1-61060-069-9|pages=227–}}</ref> Su-25s were used as development platforms for Soviet precision guided munitions, being some of the first Soviet aircraft to use such munitions in combat, typically against cave entrances or weapons storage sites. In April 1986, the Su-25 used a precision-guided weapon in combat for the first time, firing a [[Kh-25]] and [[Kh-29]] missile against enemy targets. The introduction of precision bombs and missiles allowed the Su-25 to begin flying missions at higher-altitude, reducing the risk posed by anti-aircraft artillery and shoulder launched surface-to-air missiles.<ref name="GordonDawes2002">{{cite book|author1=Yefim Gordon|author2=Alan Dawes|title=Russian Air Power|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RAYiAQAAIAAJ|year=2002|publisher=Airlife|isbn=978-1-84037-240-3|page=31}}</ref>
Due to the fact Su-25s were often tasked with flying low-altitude, subsonic, close air support missions in support of ground forces in combat, they made frequent targets for [[Mujahideen]] anti-aircraft fire and [[surface-to-air missiles]]. Some 23 aircraft were shot down over the course of the war, with an additional dozen or so were lost in non-combat related incidents, while another dozen were written off due to extensive damage, and a further nine were destroyed by bombardments on the ground in [[Kabul]] and [[Kandahar]]. In all, Su-25s represented a quarter of Soviet Air Force (VVS) fixed-wing losses in the campaign.<ref name="Mladen2013">{{cite book|author=Alexander Mladenov|title=Sukhoi Su-25 Frogfoot|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oYmHCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT91|date=20 September 2013|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=978-1-4728-0479-2|pages=91–92}}</ref>
On 16 January 1984, a Su-25 piloted by a Soviet lieutenant colonel was struck by a [[9K32 Strela-2|SA-7 missile]] and downed near [[Urgun]], Afghanistan, making it the first shootdown of a Su-25 in the war.<ref name="ejection-history.org.uk 1978">{{cite web |title=Date |website=ejection-history.org.uk |date=1978-10-17 |url=http://www.ejection-history.org.uk/Country-By-Country/Russia_USSR.htm |access-date=2018-03-07}}</ref>
In August 1988, a Su-25 piloted by Colonel [[Alexander Rutskoy]] was hit by anti-aircraft fire and crashed. Rutskoy ejected but landed on Pakistani soil where he was captured and later repatriated to the Soviets. Some sources state he was shot down by Pakistani warplanes.<ref name="attack">{{cite web |title=Sukhoi Su-25 |website=attack |url=http://www.aviastar.org/air/russia/su-25.php |access-date=2018-03-07}}</ref> The aircraft's wreckage was reportedly salvaged by Pakistan and handed over to the [[United States]].<ref name="Sirrs2016">{{cite book|author=Owen L. Sirrs|title=Pakistan's Inter-Services Intelligence Directorate: Covert Action and Internal Operations|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_S-TDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA126|date=July 2016|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-19609-9|pages=126–}}</ref> In October of that year, a Su-25 sustained a powerful hit at high-altitude north of [[Gardez]], heavily damaging it but remaining flyable. The strike was reportedly the result of a missile fired by a Pakistani fighter jet.<ref name="Madenov2015">{{cite book|author=Alexander Mladenov|title=Su-25 'Frogfoot' Units In Combat|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wbGdCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA53|date=20 April 2015|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=978-1-4728-0568-3|pages=53–54}}</ref>
In January 1989, a missile hit a Su-25 near Kabul killing the pilot in the last combat loss of the aircraft in Afghanistan.
=== Iran–Iraq War === The [[Iraqi Air Force]] was the first non-Eastern Bloc country to receive the Su-25, with Iraq receiving 69 'K' single-seat variants and four 'UBK' two-seater variants between 1986 and 1987, enough to equip two ground-attack regiments. The Su-25 saw extensive use in the latter stages of the [[Iran–Iraq War]], its first action outside of Afghanistan, in combat against Iranian forces. One Su-25K purportedly survived a direct hit from an Iranian [[MIM-23 Hawk]] surface-to-air missile battery, managing to return to base and land. In total, the Su-25 took part in 900 combat sorties in the conflict and many of their pilots were personally decorated by [[Saddam Hussein]].<ref name="Suk 1975">{{cite web |title=Suj-25 and Su-25TM, Soviet Union, Russia |website=???? – ?????????? |date=1975-02-22 |url=http://www.airforceworld.com/attacker/eng/su25-striker-frogfoot-russia-1.htm |access-date=2018-03-07}}</ref> Two Su-25Ks were lost in combat in the war, of which one was lost to Iranian air defenses.<ref name="Mlanov2015">{{cite book|author=Alexander Mladenov|title=Su-25 'Frogfoot' Units In Combat|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wbGdCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA81|date=20 April 2015|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=978-1-4728-0568-3|pages=81–}}</ref>
== 1990–2000 ==
=== Persian Gulf War === [[File:Destroyed Iraqi Su-25.jpg|thumb|right|A Su-25 Frogfoot aircraft destroyed during Operation Desert Storm]] The [[Iraqi Air Force]]'s Su-25 aircraft played little part in the [[Persian Gulf War]] as did most Iraqi aircraft. At least one Su-25 squadron saw action during the August 1990 [[Invasion of Kuwait]]. During the war, seven of the IAF's Su-25 aircraft were flown to neighboring Iran to shield them from air strikes.<ref name="Iran">{{cite web |url=http://www.janes.co.uk/defence/air_forces/news/jdw/jdw060913_1_n.shtml |title="Iran bolsters Su-25 fleet" |accessdate=2013-02-10 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071008004044/http://www.janes.co.uk/defence/air_forces/news/jdw/jdw060913_1_n.shtml |archivedate=8 October 2007 |df=dmy-all }}. ''Jane's Defence Weekly'', 13 September 2006.</ref> Two Su-25 jets were shot down by U.S. F-15C interceptors on 6 February 1991 using [[AIM-9 Sidewinder]] air-to-air missiles.<ref name="Iraqi air-air victories during the Arab Gulf War 19912">{{cite web|url=http://128.121.102.226/aakill.html |title=Coalition Air-Air Victories |accessdate=11 September 2010 |last= |first= |year=2004 |publisher=acig.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090604224140/http://128.121.102.226/aakill.html |archivedate=4 June 2009 |df=dmy }}</ref> However, most of Iraq's Su-25 fleet was destroyed on the ground in precision strikes on hardened aircraft shelters during the war and they were not used for ground attack against coalition forces.<ref name="Mnov2015">{{cite book|author=Alexander Mladenov|title=Su-25 'Frogfoot' Units In Combat|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wbGdCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA95|date=20 April 2015|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=978-1-4728-0568-3|pages=95–}}</ref>
=== Angolan Civil War ===
Angola received its first batch of Su-25 jets from the Soviet Union in 1988.<ref name="?? - ?????????? 1975">{{cite web |title=Su-25 Russia Airforce |website=???? - ?????????? |date=1975-02-22 |url=http://www.airforceworld.com/attacker/eng/su252.htm |access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref> During the [[Angolan Civil War]], the [[Angolan Air Force]] used the Su-25 against [[UNITA]] forces advancing on [[Luanda]] but to little tactical effect as they often flew bombing missions from high altitudes, reducing the aircraft's effectiveness, an issue exacerbated by a withdrawal of Soviet support in 1991 which caused serviceability issues.<ref name="Mladenov205">{{cite book|author=Alexander Mladenov|title=Su-25 'Frogfoot' Units In Combat|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wbGdCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA82|date=20 April 2015|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=978-1-4728-0568-3|pages=82–}}</ref> The Su-25 was also flown by mercenaries from the South African private military company [[Executive Outcomes]] based out of [[Saurimo Airport]] against UNITA forces beginning in the early 1990s.<ref name="Jr.Kelty2016">{{cite book|author1=Schaub Jr.|author2=Ryan Kelty|title=Private Military and Security Contractors: Controlling the Corporate Warrior|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wpg5DAAAQBAJ&pg=PA13|date=16 June 2016|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield Publishers|isbn=978-1-4422-6023-8|pages=13–}}</ref>
=== War in Abkhazia === During the [[War in Abkhazia (1992–1993)|War in Abkhazia]], the Su-25 was used by the [[Georgian Air Force]], the [[Abkhazian Air Force]], and the [[Russian Air Force]] in a series of combat actions in the breakaway province. The Georgian Air Force flew as many as 215 combat missions in the Su-25 during the war.<ref name="Mlaenov205">{{cite book|author=Alexander Mladenov|title=Su-25 'Frogfoot' Units In Combat|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wbGdCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA64|date=20 April 2015|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=978-1-4728-0568-3|pages=64–}}</ref> Russian Su-25s flying on the side of Abkhazian separatists performed numerous raids on Georgian positions near the besieged port city of [[Sukhumi]], flying out of an airfield in [[Gudauta]].<ref name="Mladenov013">{{cite book|author=Alexander Mladenov|title=Sukhoi Su-25 Frogfoot|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mbCdCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA56|date=20 September 2013|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=978-1-4728-0478-5|pages=56–}}</ref><ref name="The New York Times 1993">{{cite web |title=Georgian Regional Capital Under Aerial Attack |website=The New York Times |date=1993-09-21 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/09/21/world/georgian-regional-capital-under-aerial-attack.html |access-date=2018-03-11}}</ref> On at least one occasion, a Russian Su-25 bombed a residential district of Sukhumi, killing a civilian and destroying numerous homes and other buildings.<ref name="UPI 1993">{{cite web |title=Georgia blames Russia for attack |website=UPI |date=1993-02-21 |url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1993/02/21/Georgia-blames-Russia-for-attack/9073730270800/ |access-date=2018-03-11}}</ref> During the conflict, the Russian government asserted that Su-25s bombing Georgian positions were not Russian but, in fact, Georgian warplanes with painted Russian insignia, a claim that drew much doubt since many of these Su-25 aircraft were flying uninhibited through Russian airspace.<ref name="Human Rights Watch | Defending Human Rights Worldwide 1992">{{cite web |title=RUSSIA |publisher=Human Rights Watch |date=1992-06-15 |url=https://www.hrw.org/reports/1993/russia/ |access-date=2018-03-11}}</ref> On 6 January 1993, a Georgian Su-25 crashed in Abkhazia province with the pilot ejecting to safety. On 19 March 1993, a Russian Air Force Su-25 piloted by Major Vazlav Shipko was shot down by Georgian air defenses near Sukhumi, however some sources state he was flying a [[Su-27]]. On 4 July 1993, a Georgian Su-25 was struck by an Abkhazian surface-to-air missile, forcing the aircraft into the sea off Sukhumi and killing the pilot.<ref name="ejection-history.org.uk 1993">{{cite web |title=2005 |website=ejection-history.org.uk |date=1993-02-05 |url=http://www.ejection-history.org.uk/PROJECT/YEAR_Pages/1993.htm |access-date=2018-03-11}}</ref>
=== Eritrean–Ethiopian War === The [[Ethiopian Air Force]] operated the Su-25 during the [[Eritrean–Ethiopian War]], after receiving a delivery of a pair of Su-25Ts and two Su-25UBKs from the Russian Air Force in March 2000. Combat operations were flown from [[Mek'ele]] and [[Bishoftu|Debre Zeyit]].<ref name="Mladenov201">{{cite book|author=Alexander Mladenov|title=Su-25 'Frogfoot' Units In Combat|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0Y2HCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT139|date=20 April 2015|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=978-1-4728-0569-0|page=82}}</ref> On 15 May 2000, a Su-25 piloted by [[Flight Lieutenant]] Wondu Ghenda was shot down by an [[Eritrean Air Force]] [[MiG-29]], killing the pilot.<ref>[https://www.webcitation.org/5nDhCzUZj?url=http://www.acig.org/artman/publish/article_189.shtml "Ethiopia."] acig.org. Retrieved: 10 August 2010.</ref>
=== Nagorno-Karabak War === During the [[Nagorno-Karabakh War]], both [[Armenia]] and [[Azerbaijan]] used Su-25 aircraft inherited from the Soviet Union.<ref name="The National Interest 2018">{{cite web |title=Russia's Su-25: Moscow's 'A-10' Is a Virtual 'Flying Tank' |website=The National Interest |date=2018-02-06 |url=http://nationalinterest.org/blog/the-buzz/russias-su-25-moscows-10-virtual-flying-tank-24381 |access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref> However, Armenia's use of its modest five jets during the war was minimal<ref name="Pikes 2018">{{cite web |last=Pike |first=John |title=Armenian Air Force |website=GlobalSecurity.org |date=2018-03-09 |url=https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/armenia/af.htm |access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref> while the Azeri Air Force utilized it heavily in strafing and bombing missions against Armenian targets.<ref name="Brzezinski2016">{{cite book|author=Zbigniew K Brzezinski|title=Russia and the Commonwealth of Independent States: Documents, Data, and Analysis|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=58AYDQAAQBAJ&pg=PT1341|date=17 September 2016|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-1-315-48147-0|pages=1341–}}</ref> At least three Su-25s operated by Azerbaijan were downed during the conflict. One was shot down in 1992 by a missile while conducting a ground attack mission over Armenian territory.<ref name="UPI 1992">{{cite web |title=Plane downed over disputed enclave |website=UPI |date=1992-07-22 |url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1992/07/22/Plane-downed-over-disputed-enclave/9014711777600/ |access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref> In 1994, two were lost in separate incidents. One in February where the aircraft was struck by ground fire causing the pilot to eject and become captured. Another Su-25 was lost the following April with the pilot managing to eject.<ref name="ejection-history.org.uk 1994">{{cite web |title=2005 |website=ejection-history.org.uk |date=1994-01-05 |url=http://www.ejection-history.org.uk/project/year_pages/1994.htm |access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref> [[Human Rights Watch]] alleges in a 1994 report that Azerbaijan used its Su-25 aircraft in an indiscriminate manner against civilian population centers in Nagorno-Karabakh and Armenia.<ref>https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/AZER%20Conflict%20in%20N-K%20Dec94.pdf</ref>
=== Chechen War === Su-25s saw heavy use by the [[Russian Air Force]] again during the [[First Chechen War|First]] and [[Second Chechen War]]. During the First Chechen War, some 140 Su-25s flew 5,300 strike sorties, notably playing an instrumental role in the destruction and the capture of the heavily defended [[Presidential Palace, Grozny|Grozny Presidential Palace]], dropping [[BETAB-500]] anti-concrete bombs on it.<ref name="The National Interest 2017">{{cite web |title=Russia's Very Own A-10: Meet the Su-25 Frogfoot |website=The National Interest |date=2017-06-21 |url=http://nationalinterest.org/blog/the-buzz/russias-very-own-10-meet-the-su-25-frogfoot-21257 |access-date=2018-03-08}}</ref><ref name="Sukhoi015">{{cite book|author=Alexander Mladenov|title=Su-25 'Frogfoot' Units In Combat|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wbGdCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA71|date=20 April 2015|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=978-1-4728-0568-3|pages=71–}}</ref> However, Russian Su-25s rarely operated at night or in poor weather due to faulty equipment and insufficient training, and aircraft rarely used precision munitions, utilizing unguided bombs and rockets for the most part instead.<ref name="GeoHistory 2006">{{cite web |title=Military Learning Between the Chechen Wars |website=GeoHistory |date=2006-10-24 |url=http://geohistory.today/military-learning-chechen-wars/ |access-date=2018-03-08}}</ref> This lack of precision munitions and poor training led to several [[friendly fire]] incidents where Russian aircraft hit buildings occupied by Russian troops. However, Russian air losses during the campaign were low due to a lack of capable air defenses. Four Su-25s were lost in combat.
[[File:Evstafiev-chechnya-palace-gunman.jpg|thumb|left|Presidential palace in Grozny in 1995.]] * On 4 February 1995, a Su-25 piloted by Major Nikolay Bairov crashed three miles southeast of [[Grozny]] after being hit by [[ZSU-23-4]] anti-aircraft fire. The pilot was able to eject but was still killed after his parachute failed to fully deploy.<ref name="ejection-history.org.uk 1995">{{cite web |title=2005 |website=ejection-history.org.uk |date=1995-01-13 |url=http://www.ejection-history.org.uk/project/year_pages/1995.htm |access-date=2018-03-08}}</ref> Another Su-25 piloted by Lieutenant Colonel Evgeny Derkulsky was damaged but was able to return to base. * On 5 May 1995, a Su-25 piloted by Colonel Vladimir Sarabeyev from the [[4th Air and Air Defence Forces Army|4th Air Army]] was hit by 12.7mm [[DShK]] fire while flying a low altitude patrol near the village of Serzhen-Yurt. The bullets pierced the unarmored side canopy glass of the cockpit, killing the pilot and causing the plane to crash. Chechen rebels managed to recover maps and charts from the wreckage.<ref name="Billingsley2013">{{cite book|author=Dodge Billingsley|title=Fangs of the Lone Wolf: Chechen Tactics in the Russian-Chechen War 1994–2009|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3pS0DAAAQBAJ&pg=PA10|date=19 October 2013|publisher=Helion|isbn=978-1-911096-76-4|pages=10–}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Daily Report: Central Eurasia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r-AVAQAAMAAJ|year=1996|publisher=The Service|page=34}}</ref> * On 4 April 1996, a Su-25 piloted by Major Alexander Matvienko flying a reconnaissance mission near Goiskoye was shot down with a Stinger missile forcing the pilot to eject. The pilot was successfully rescued by helicopter.<ref name="ejection-history.org.uk 19962">{{cite web |title=1996 |website=ejection-history.org.uk |date=1996-01-08 |url=http://www.ejection-history.org.uk/project/year_pages/1996.htm |access-date=2018-03-08}}</ref> * On 5 May 1996, a Su-25UB crewed by Colonel Igor Sviryidov and Major Oleg Isayev was shot down by a [[9K34 Strela-3]] shoulder-launched surface to air missile while flying near Serzhen-Yurt, killing both pilots.<ref name="www.skywar.ru">{{cite web |title=Chechenya – Air force in local wars |website=www.skywar.ru |url=http://skywar.ru/chechenyaen.html |language=ru |access-date=2018-03-08}}</ref>
During the initial push into Chechnya, Russian Su-25 and [[Su-24]] strike aircraft destroyed the majority of the dilapidated Chechen air fleet on the ground in a matter of hours. In 1995, facilitated by clear weather, air cover provided by Su-25s allowed Russian troops to push across the [[Argun River (Caucasus)|Argun River]] and into the towns of [[Gudermes]] and [[Shali, Chechen Republic|Shali]], setting the stage for a decisive victory over separatist forces in the region.<ref>Russian Airpower in the Second Chechen War pg. 11</ref>
Chechen separatist leader [[Dzhokhar Dudayev]] was killed on 21 April 1996, after a Su-25 fired two laser-guided missiles at his position, after an [[Beriev A-50|A-50]] aircraft pinpointed his [[satellite phone]] signal and relayed the location to the Su-25.<ref name="Madsen2013">{{cite book|author=Wayne Madsen|title=National Security Agency Surveillance: Reflections and Revelations 2001–2013|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BWGiBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA74|year=2013|publisher=Lulu.com|isbn=978-1-304-27213-3|page=74}}</ref> A picture purportedly from the warhead as it approached Dudayev later surfaced in ''[[Argumenty i Fakty]]'', a Russian newspaper.
In 1999, Russian Su-25s once again saw heavy use in Chechnya with the onset of the Second Chechen War in 1999. During the war, the Su-25 was again primarily a close air support platform, providing support for ground troops at low altitude in conjunction with [[Mi-24 Hind]] and [[Ka-50]] helicopters while [[Su-24]]s flew higher altitude precision strikes.<ref name="LaiKamphausen2011">{{cite book|author1=David Lai|author2=Roy Kamphausen|title=Chinese Lessons from Other Peoples' Wars|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y_eSUYTbBiAC|year=2011|publisher=Strategic Studies Institute, U.S. Army War College|isbn=978-1-58487-511-6|page=304}}</ref> Su-25s would often fly at altitudes between 16,000 and 20,000 feet before visually acquiring and attacking their targets at lower altitudes, typically utilizing unguided rockets and bombs. For more accurate strikes, Su-25s used [[Kh-25]]ML and [[Kh-29]] laser-guided missiles. In a newer tactic not utilized during the First Chechen War, Su-25s engaged in "free hunt" operations, flying ahead of larger Russian formations in visual search of targets of opportunity. On occasion, these flights would be accompanied by reconnaissance Su-24s to increase the probability of locating mobile targets.<ref>Russian Airpower in the Second Chechen War pg. 32–34</ref>
A new all-weather with night capability variant, the Su-25T, was introduced into combat during this conflict with notable successes with six of the aircraft flying a total of 20 sorties throughout the fighting. The 'T' model had improved sighting and was modified to include the new [[S-13 rocket|B-13]] rocket pod.<ref name="Mladenova2013">{{cite book|author=Alexander Mladenov|title=Sukhoi Su-25 Frogfoot|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mbCdCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA35|date=20 September 2013|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=978-1-4728-0478-5|pages=35–}}</ref>
Six Su-25 aircraft were lost during the Second Chechen War. * On 3 October 1999, a Su-25 flying a reconnaissance mission over the village of Tolstoy-Yurt was hit by a missile and shot down, killing the pilot. * On 9 September 1999, a Su-25 from the 960th Air Assault Regiment was struck in the fuel line by ground fire, possibly by a shoulder-launced surface-to-air missile causing the pilot to eject and crash. * On 13 December 1999, the rocket pod of a Su-25 piloted by Colonel Sergey Borisyuk malfunction resulting in a fire that caused the pilot to eject. Col. Borisyuk was rescued on the ground. * On 22 January 2000, a Su-25 was hit by a [[MANPAD]], resulting in the loss of the left-engine. The pilot was able to land the aircraft safely however the aircraft was written off. * On 14 June 2001, a pair of Su-25s piloted by Lieutenant Colonel Yuriy Yakimenko and Captain Oleg Podsitkov crashed into mountainous terrain, killing both pilots. * On 29 April 2002, a Su-25 piloted by Major Igor Bezryadin crashed after entering an unrecoverable nosedive.<ref>https://wikileaks.org/gifiles/attach/178/178771_mdb_2_2010_adv.pdf</ref>
== 2000–2010 ==
=== Macedonian insurgency === [[File:Su-25UB Macedonia (20897568328).jpg|thumb|left| Su-25UB that was used by the Macedonian Air Force]] In June 2001, the government of [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]] procured four Su-25 aircraft (three single seat, one two-seater) from [[Ukraine]] which promptly entered service in the [[Macedonian Air Force]]. In the first aerial combat action of the Macedonian military, they were used to combat ethnic Albanian [[2001 insurgency in the Republic of Macedonia|insurgents in Macedonia]]. Mostly flown from an air force base near [[Petrovec, Republic of Macedonia|Petrovec]], these aircraft were piloted by Ukrainian mercenaries as Macedonia did not have any pilots trained in flying the aircraft. They saw heavy use in ground attack missions against insurgents.<ref name="Washington Post 2001">{{cite web |title=Ethnic Albanian Rebels Wary About Macedonia Peace Deal |website=Washington Post |date=2001-08-10 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/2001/08/10/ethnic-albanian-rebels-wary-about-macedonia-peace-deal/8d3f448f-2319-4876-83d7-1efef3b80fa8/ |access-date=2018-03-12}}</ref> During the Battle of Raduša in August 2001, the Su-25s supported beleaguered security forces in the town alongside Mi-24 helicopters.<ref name="The Associated Press 2001">{{cite web |author=The Associated Press |title=On Eve of Peace Deal, Fighting in Macedonia Continues |website=The New York Times |date=2001-08-12 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/08/12/international/europe/on-eve-of-peace-deal-fighting-in-macedonia-continues.html |access-date=2018-03-12}}</ref><ref name="Phillips2004">{{cite book|author=John Phillips|title=Macedonia: Warlords and Rebels in the Balkans|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SB1OrH8iZtcC&pg=PA143|year=2004|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=978-1-86064-841-0|pages=143–}}</ref>
=== Ivorian Civil War === Four Su-25 aircraft (two one seaters, and two two-seaters) were procured from [[Belarus]] by the [[Ivory Coast]] in 2004. After the outbreak of the [[First Ivorian Civil War]], the government of [[Laurent Gbagbo]] used his air force to bomb rebel forces. On 6 November 2004, a pair of Su-25 aircraft based out of [[Abidjan]] and piloted by mixed crews of Ivorians and Belorussians bombed a French encampment near the city of [[Bouaké]], killing nine French [[Opération Licorne|Licorne]] peacekeepers and an American aid worker, and destroying several vehicles. The attack triggered the French to destroy the Ivorian air force, firing [[MILAN]] missiles at the two Su-25s that had attacked the French troops shortly after they landed, damaging them, and seizing the other two and disabling them.<ref name="Mladenov Ugolini Hector 2015 p. 143">{{cite book |last=Mladenov |first=A. |last2=Ugolini |first2=R. |last3=Hector |first3=G. |title=Su-25 'Frogfoot' Units In Combat |publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing |series=Combat Aircraft |year=2015 |isbn=978-1-4728-0569-0 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0Y2HCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT143 |access-date=2018-03-14 |page=143}}</ref><ref name="BBC NEWS 2004">{{cite web |title=France attacks Ivorian airbase |website=BBC NEWS |date=2004-11-06 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/3988769.stm |access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|language=fr|title= Soldats tués à Bouaké : la France a laissé faire |work=[[Libération]]|date= 3 July 2006|first= Thomas|last= Hofnung |url=http://www.liberation.fr/evenement/2006/07/03/soldats-tues-a-bouake-la-france-a-laisse-faire_44887}}</ref>
=== Sudan and Chad === The [[Sudanese Air Force]] has obtained fifteen Su-25 aircraft from Belarus since 2008. Despite Sudanese government assurances that the aircraft would not be used in the [[War in Darfur|Darfur conflict]], United Nations inspectors discovered four Su-25 bombers at [[El Fasher Airport]] in the region and numerous reports have surfaced of the aircraft taking part in indiscriminate targeting of villages.<ref name="The Moscow Times">{{cite web |title=Su-25 Jets Stun UN Envoys in Darfur |website=The Moscow Times |url=http://themoscowtimes.com/news/su-25-jets-stun-un-envoys-in-darfur-2586 |access-date=2018-03-12}}</ref><ref name="Nichols 2013">{{cite web |last=Nichols |first=Michelle |title=Sudan violating sanctions with Darfur air strikes: U.N. panel |publisher=Reuters |date=2013-03-01 |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-sudan-darfur-un/sudan-violating-sanctions-with-darfur-air-strikes-u-n-panel-idUSBRE9200YY20130301 |access-date=2018-03-12}}</ref> [[File:Chad Air Force Sukhoi Su-25 inflight.jpeg|thumb|right|Chad Air Force Sukhoi Su-25 inflight]] Chad obtained six Su-25 jets from Ukraine to enhance its close air support capability.<ref>{{cite book|title=Jane's Intelligence Weekly|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dDMqAQAAMAAJ|year=2009|publisher=IHS (Global)}}</ref> In May 2009, the Su-25s operated by the [[Chadian Air Force]] bombed rebel columns in southeastern Chad, near [[Abéché]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Cable: 09NDJAMENA151_a |url=https://wikileaks.org/plusd/cables/09NDJAMENA151_a.html |accessdate=2018-03-12}}</ref><ref name="Pike 2018">{{cite web |last=Pike |first=John |title=Chad Air Force |website=GlobalSecurity.org |date=2018-03-12 |url=https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/africa/cd-af.htm |access-date=2018-03-12}}</ref>
=== Russo-Georgia War === The Su-25 was once again pressed into service in the skies of Georgia during the [[Russo-Georgian War]] in 2008, seeing extensive use by both the Russian and Georgian air forces. At the beginning of the war, Georgia had a fleet of twelve Su-25 aircraft (two of them trainers) at its disposal. The aircraft saw particularly heavy use in fighting around [[Tskhinvali]], the South Ossetian capital. Out of six Russian aircraft lost in the war, three were Su-25s. All were most likely lost to friendly fire.<ref name="Editorial 2009">{{cite web |last=Editorial |first=Reuters |title=Friendly fire downed Russia jets in Georgia-report |website=U.S. |date=2009-07-08 |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSL8262192 |access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref>
The first Russian air loss of the campaign was a Su-25 piloted by Lieutenant Colonel Oleg Terebunsky of the 368th Attack Aviation Regiment, shot down over the territory of South Ossetia near the Zarsk pass, between [[Java (town)|Dzhava]] and [[Tskhinvali]]. He was hit by a [[MANPAD]] missile fired by South Ossetian militia around 6.00 p.m. on 8 August, in a case of friendly fire. Earlier in the day, a flight of four Georgian Su-25 planes had attacked a Russian army convoy in the same area. This was one of the few missions conducted by Georgia's Su-25s during the brief conflict as Tblisi reasoned that its aircraft would soon become easy targets for Russian interceptors. The aircraft returned to their bases and were hidden under camouflage netting to prevent them from being located.
At 10:30 a.m. on 9 August, a Su-25 piloted by Colonel Sergey Kobylash, commander of the 368th Attack Aviation Regiment, was shot down during an attack on a Georgian military formation south of Tskhinvali, on the Gori-Tskhinvali road. After making his initial approach, Kolybash's aircraft was struck by a missile that impacted his left engine, rendering it inoperable. Not long after, as Kobylash was returning to base at an altitude of 1,000 meters, a MANPAD missile struck his right engine, leaving the plane without thrust. Kobylash ejected north of Tskhinvali in a South Ossetian village of the Georgian enclave of in the Great Liakh gorge, where he was recovered by a Russian combat search and rescue team. Shortly after Kobylash was rescued, South Ossetian militants made the claim they had downed a Georgian Su-25 however this possibility was rejected as Georgia's air force had ceased air operations the day before, more than likely making the shootdown of the Su-25 another incident of friendly fire.
At 1:00 p.m. on 9 August, another Su-25 from the 368th Attack Aviation Regiment, piloted by Major Vladimir Edamenko, was struck by fire from a Russian [[ZSU-23-4]] Shilka anti-aircraft gun near [[Java (town)|Dzhava]] killing the pilot. Two hours later, a Su-25 mistakenly attacked a Russian military convoy near Liakhva, destroying a fuel tanker and injuring several troops. The Russian soldiers returned fire with a MANPAD damaging the Su-25.
Russian Su-25s also hit numerous targets deep inside Georgian territory including the Marneuli air base, however none of Georgia's Su-25 aircraft were lost. In Tskhinvali, Russian Su-25s attacked Georgian infantrymen as they rested in the outskirts of the city. The strikes killed 20 Georgian troops and injured countless more, causing the entire battalion to abandon their equipment and flee sparking rumors about the battalion's annihilation which played a hand in the Georgian withdrawal from the city. The [[Tbilisi Aircraft Manufacturing]], a factory that produces Su-25s, was also bombed damaging a runway but otherwise causing no casualties.<ref>http://www.cast.ru/files/The_Tanks_of_August_sm_eng.pdf</ref><ref name="Jamestown">{{cite web |title=The Russia-Georgia Conflict as Analyzed by the Center of Analysis of Strategies and Technologies in Moscow |publisher=Jamestown Foundation |url=https://jamestown.org/program/the-russia-georgia-conflict-as-analyzed-by-the-center-of-analysis-of-strategies-and-technologies-in-moscow/ |access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref>
On the night of 8 August, a Georgian Su-25 was shot down by a Russian Su-27. The pilot managed to eject but was reportedly executed by fighters on the ground.
== 2010–present ==
=== Syrian Civil War === In September 2015, the [[U.S. Department of Defense]] released satellite photos of an airfield in Latakia, a Syrian government-controlled city, showing twelve Su-25 planes on the tarmac.<ref name="Frogfoots on the apron">{{cite web |author=UNIAN redaction |title=Pentagon releases satellite images of Russian aircraft in Syria |website=UNIAN |date=2015-09-22 |url=https://www.unian.info/world/1130803-pentagon-releases-satellite-images-of-russian-aircraft-in-syria.html |access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref> Airstrikes by Russian forces in support of the [[Bashar Assad|Assad government]] began later that same month. The aircraft have been used predominantly to strike opposition vehicles, fighting positions, artillery pieces, and other non-strategic targets in the country.<ref name="McLeary 2016">{{cite web |last=McLeary |first=Paul |title=Here’s the Bomb Russia Is Using to Flatten Aleppo |website=Foreign Policy |date=2016-09-26 |url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2016/09/26/heres-the-bomb-russia-is-using-to-flatten-aleppo/ |access-date=2018-03-15}}</ref>
In January 2015, Syrian Air Force MiG-29s and Russian Su-25s took part in a joint-strike mission against militant targets in what was the first time Syrian and Russian warplanes flew a combat mission together.<ref name="РИА Новости 2016">{{cite web |title=ВКС России и ВВС Сирии впервые выполнили совместную боевую задачу в небе |website=РИА Новости |date=2016-01-14 |url=https://ria.ru/syria_chronicle/20160114/1359683603.html |language=ru |access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref> [[File:Sukhoi Su-25 at Latakia (11).jpg|thumb|A pair of Sukhoi Su-25s take off at Latakia]] In 2016, Alexander Galkin, the Russia’s [[Southern Military District]] commander, said Su-25s had flown more than 1,600 sorties and dropped around 6,000 bombs since the beginning of Russia's intervention in September 2015.<ref name="Busy Su-25s">{{cite web |title=Russian Air Force Su-25 Frogfoot attack aircraft dropped 6,000 (mostly unguided) bombs over Syria |website=The Aviationist |date=2016-03-19 |url=https://theaviationist.com/2016/03/19/russian-air-force-su-25-frogfoot-attack-aircraft-dropped-6000-mostly-unguided-bombs-over-syria/ |access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref> In September 2017, the [[Ministry of Defence (Russia)|Russian Ministry of Defence]] released a video showing two Su-25s helping to rescue Russian troops encircled by [[Tahrir al-Sham]] militants.<ref name="War on the Rocks 2017">{{cite web |title=Not-So-Soft Power: Russia’s Military Police in Syria |website=War on the Rocks |date=2017-10-02 |url=https://warontherocks.com/2017/10/not-so-soft-power-russias-military-police-in-syria/ |access-date=2018-03-15}}</ref> Two months later, a pair of Su-25s flying near [[Mayadin]], in eastern Syria, was suddenly intercepted by a U.S. F-22 jet which abruptly entered the flight path of the two Russian warplanes and deployed [[Flare (countermeasure)|flares]] and [[Chaff (countermeasure)|chaff]] in an attempt to cause the Su-25s to change their heading. The United States claimed the incident was not a provocation but a response to the Russian jets crossing the [[Euphrates River]] deconfliction{{what|date=August 2018}} line and not responding to radio calls.<ref name="Trevithick 2017">{{cite web |last=Trevithick |first=Joseph |title=Russian Su-25 Almost Hits US F-22 During Intercept Over Syria, But Is There More Going On? |website=The Drive |date=2017-12-15 |url=http://www.thedrive.com/the-war-zone/17000/russian-su-25-almost-hits-us-f-22-during-intercept-over-syria-but-is-there-more-going-on |access-date=2018-03-15}}</ref>
On 3 February 2018, a Russian Su-25 piloted by Major [[Roman Filipov]] flying over [[Idlib Governorate]] was hit by a surface-to-air missile, downing the aircraft and forcing the pilot to eject. Filipov committed suicide to avoid capture on the ground.
=== Ukrainian crisis === [[File:Ukrainian Air Force Su-25UB with two MiG-29s (9-13) in background.jpg|thumb|left|Su-25UB of the Ukrainian Air Force]] The [[Ukrainian Air Force]] has made use of its fleet of Su-25 warplanes in the [[War in Donbass]], using them for strike missions against pro-Russian separatists, and at times Russian government forces. During the [[First Battle of Donetsk Airport]], Su-25s were witnessed partaking in ground attack missions, at times firing unguided rockets at separatist positions.<ref name="Su-25s Donetsk Airport">{{cite web |title=Impressive Videos of the Ukrainian Air Strikes on Donetsk |website=The Aviationist |date=2014-05-27 |url=https://theaviationist.com/2014/05/27/ukrainian-offensive-donetsk/ |access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref> During fighting at [[Kramatorsk Airport]], Su-25s were used to deliver supplies to besieged Ukrainian troops, flying at a low altitude and parachuting provisions.<ref name="Mladenov Ugolini Hector 2015 p. 153">{{cite book |last=Mladenov |first=A. |last2=Ugolini |first2=R. |last3=Hector |first3=G. |title=Su-25 'Frogfoot' Units In Combat |publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing |series=Combat Aircraft |year=2015 |isbn=978-1-4728-0569-0 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0Y2HCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT153 |access-date=2018-03-14 |page=153}}</ref> A rocket and strafing attack on a regional administration building in [[Luhansk]] was purportedly carried out by a Ukrainian Su-25 aircraft.<ref name="Armament Research Services 2014">{{cite web |title=Ukrainian Air Force strike Lugansk with S-8KOM rockets – Armament Research Services |website=Armament Research Services |date=2014-06-03 |url=http://armamentresearch.com/ukrainian-air-force-strike-lugansk-with-s-8kom-rockets/ |access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref> During the [[Battle of Debaltseve]] in 2015, Russian Air Force Su-25s participated in the route of Ukrainian troops and the subsequent capture of the city.<ref name="Русская весна 2015">{{cite web |title=МОЛНИЯ: Ополчение применило авиацию под Дебальцево - 2 штурмовика СУ-25 нанесли удар по позициям 40-го батальона, - источник |website=Русская весна |date=2015-02-09 |url=http://rusvesna.su/news/1423482673 |language=ru |access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref> After the shootdown of [[Malaysia Airlines Flight 17]] in 2014, the Russian military cited the appearance of a Ukrainian Su-25 on its radar in the vicinity of the airliner as evidence that the Ukrainian military were the culprits behind the shootdown.<ref name="Rudin 2016">{{cite web |last=Rudin |first=Mike |title=Conspiracy Files: Who shot down MH17? |website=BBC News |date=2016-04-25 |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-35706048 |access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref>
Four Ukrainian Su-25 aircraft have been lost in combat during the conflict. On 16 July 2014, a Ukrainian Su-25 was struck by a missile and downed over eastern Ukraine. The pilot was able to eject and survived. The Ukrainian government placed the blame for the shootdown on a Russian Su-27 fighter jet.<ref name="Korrespondent.net">{{cite web |author=Korrespondent.net |title=Российский самолет сбил ракетой украинский Су-25 – СНБО |website=Korrespondent.net |url=https://korrespondent.net/ukraine/politics/3393663-rossyiskyi-samolet-sbyl-raketoi-ukraynskyi-su-25-snbo |language=ru |access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref>
On 23 July 2014, a pair of Su-25 jets flying near separatist-held [[Savur-Mohyla]] were shot down while flying at an altitude of 17,000 feet (5,200 meters). Both pilots were able to eject. The Ukrainian military said the aircraft had been downed by a long-range missile system, possibly fired from Russia.<ref name="USA TODAY 2014">{{cite web |title=2 Ukrainian jet fighters shot down in rebel-held area |website=USA Today |date=2014-07-23 |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2014/07/23/ukraine-rebels-separatists-fighter-jet-shot-down/13034005/ |access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref>
On 29 August 2014, a Su-25 flying near Luhansk was shot down by a surface-to-air missile. The pilot ejected and was recovered by Ukrainian troops.<ref name="ЛIГА.Новости 2014">{{cite web |title=В Донбассе из российского ЗРК сбили украинский самолет Су-25 |website=ЛIГА.Новости |date=2014-08-29 |url=http://news.liga.net/news/politics/3106003-v_donbasse_iz_rossiyskogo_zrk_sbili_ukrainskiy_samolet_su_25.htm |language=ru |access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref>
=== Iraqi Civil War (2014–present) === In late June 2014, twelve Su-25 planes arrived in [[Iraq]] aboard cargo planes after being purchased second-hand from Russia, entering combat service shortly later in the [[Iraqi Civil War (2014–present)|war against the Islamic State]], despite having few munitions in its stockpile compatible with the type. The delivery was accompanied by technicians in order to train the Iraqis in the plane's operation and maintenance. The purchase was made after several delays complicated Baghdad's purchase of U.S. [[F-16]] fighters.<ref name="Al Jazeera 2014">{{cite web |title=Iraq takes delivery of Russian fighter jets |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=2014-06-29 |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/06/iraq-takes-delivery-russian-fighter-jets-201462944837214478.html |access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref><ref name="Nordland 2014">{{cite web |last=Nordland |first=Rod |title=Russian Jets and Experts Sent to Iraq to Aid Army |website=The New York Times |date=2014-06-28 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/30/world/middleeast/iraq.html |access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref> Seven more Su-25s from [[Iran]] arrived in Iraq before the end of June as well. These aircraft were formerly Iraqi Air Force jets that had fled to Iran during the 1990–1991 Gulf War. Experts noted that some of the aircraft has visible signs of wear and corrosion.<ref name="The Aviationist 2014">{{cite web |title=[Video] Iraqi Air Force receives surplus Russian Air Force Su-25 attack planes to fight ISIS |website=The Aviationist |date=2014-06-30 |url=https://theaviationist.com/2014/06/30/video-iraqi-air-force-receives-surplus-russian-air-force-su-25-attack-planes-to-fight-isis/ |access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref> In 2015, Iraqi pilots received training in Belarus on flying the Su-25.<ref name="AeroHisto 2015">{{cite web |title=Iraqi pilots train in Belarus and Pakistan |website=AeroHisto |date=2015-09-21 |url=http://aerohisto.blogspot.com/2015/09/iraqi-pilots-train-in-belarus-and.html |access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref> By 2016, Iraq had 21 Su-25s in its possession.<ref name="Adel 2016">{{cite web |last=Adel |first=Loaa |title=Iraq has 21 Sukhoi aircraft |website=Iraq news, the latest Iraq news by Iraqi News |date=2016-09-05 |url=https://www.iraqinews.com/baghdad-politics/iraq-has-21-sukhoi-aircraft/ |access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref>
Iraqi Air Force Su-25s were used for close air support during the [[Battle of Ramadi (2015–16)|Battle of Ramadi]] and other battles in western [[Anbar Province]].<ref name="Funker530 2015">{{cite web |title=Cockpit Cam: Iraqi SU-25 Frogfoot Dropping Bombs On ISIS |website=Funker530 |date=2015-11-16 |url=https://www.funker530.com/cockpit-cam-iraqi-su-25-frogfoot-dropping-bombs-on-isis/ |access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref><ref name="Su-25 Iraq Vid.2">{{cite web |title=Iraq AF Sukhoi Su-25 conducting bombardment of ISIS positions in western Anbar Province, Al-Qa'im District. - Iraq news map in English – News from Baghdad, Hawija operation and Kurdistan referendum |website=Iraq news map in English – News from Baghdad, Hawija operation and Kurdistan referendum – iraq.liveuamap.com |date=2017-10-22 |url=https://iraq.liveuamap.com/en/2017/22-october-iraq-af-sukhoi-su25-conducting-bombardment-of |access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref> On 12 August 2014, a Su-25 piloted by Iraqi Colonel Jalil Al Awadi crashed after takeoff at [[Muthenna Air Base]], severely damaging the plane and killing the pilot. Another Su-25 was withdrawn from service after suffering damage when it was hit by a surface-to-air missile during a mission over [[Kirkuk]].<ref name="War Is Boring 2017">{{cite web |title=Let’s Account for All of Iraq’s Tank-Busting Jets |website=War Is Boring |date=2017-02-15 |url=https://warisboring.com/lets-account-for-all-of-iraqs-tank-busting-jets/ |access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref>

{{Start date and age|2016|10|02}} | url = {{URL|meethue.com}} }} '''Philips Hue''' is a line of color changing [[LED lamps]] and white bulbs which can be controlled wirelessly. It was introduced in October 2012 and was updated in 2015 and 2016. The lamps are currently created and manufactured by Signify N.V., formerly the Philips Lighting division of [[Philips|Royal Philips N.V.]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.theandroidsoul.com/signify-new-name-philips-lighting/|title=Signify is the new company name of Philips Lighting, the maker of Hue smart bulbs|date=2018-04-13|work=TAS|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en-GB}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.ledsmagazine.com/articles/2018/06/signify-releases-hue-sync-hoping-to-launch-the-era-of-immersive-home-entertainment-lighting.html/|title=Signify releases Hue Sync, hoping to launch the era of immersive home entertainment lighting|date=2018-06-04|work=LEDs Magazine|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en-GB}} ==Concept and design== The Hue system was released in October 2012 as an [[Apple Store]] exclusive.{{cite news|last1=News|first1=ABC|title=Philips Hue: The Light Bulb You Can Control With Your Phone|url=http://abcnews.go.com/technology/t/blogEntry?id=17585799|accessdate=26 January 2018|work=ABC News}} The Hue system was marketed as the first iOS controlled lighting appliance.{{cite news|last1=Porges|first1=Seth|title=The Best Product of 2012: The Philips Hue LED Lighting System|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/sethporges/2012/12/28/the-best-product-of-2012-the-philips-hue-led-lighting-system/#33b2df965dda|accessdate=11 November 2016|work=Forbes}} It uses the [[ZigBee|Zigbee lighting protocol]] to communicate, and can be controlled via smartphone apps over cellular network, Ethernet or [[Wi-Fi]] via a Zigbee–Ethernet bridge wired to a router. The initial system had bulbs capable of producing up to 600 [[lumen (unit)|lumens]] while the newer systems have bulbs that shine up to 800 lumens. The newer system also features [[HomeKit]] compatibility.{{cite web|title=Philips Hue 2.0 Starter Kit review: A new Hue, with Siri, too|url=https://www.cnet.com/products/philips-hue-white-and-color-ambience-starter-kit-a19/|website=CNET|accessdate=11 November 2016}} In July 2018, an outdoor version of the Philips Hue suite was introduced, {{Cite news|url=http://www.zdnet.com/article/philips-hue-outdoor-iot/|title=Philips Hue outdoor connected lighting hits US, Europe this July|last=Smith|first=Jake|date=12 March 2018|work=[[ZDNet]]|access-date=22 March 2018}} and in October 2018 a suite of entertainment-focused, free-standing light fittings.{{cite web|title=What Philips Hue can actually do|url=https://www.smartdigs.co.uk/know/philips-hue-lighting|website=Smartdigs|accessdate=22 November 2018}} ==Security concerns== Security issues have been noted in the product including an issue in which the bulbs were able to be remotely controlled over the Internet by attackers with inexpensive equipment. In another proof-of-concept, researchers were able to remotely control light bulbs using a drone flying outside a window.{{cite web|title=New study details a security flaw with Philips Hue smart bulbs|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/new-study-details-a-security-flaw-with-philips-hue-smart-bulbs/|website=CNET|accessdate=11 November 2016}} ==Reception== In an article in Forbes, Sath Porges called Phillips Hue the "best product of 2012". PC Magazine reviewed the white variation and named it as an editors' choice and said it was bright and affordable and had lots of features.{{cite web|last1=Torres|first1=Timothy|title=Philips Hue White|url=https://www.pcmag.com/review/344603/philips-hue-white|website=PCMAG|accessdate=11 November 2016}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Commons category}} {{Philips}} [[Category:Philips products]] [[Category:Lighting]] [[Category:Home automation]] [[Category:Proprietary hardware]]

{{Expert-subject|Psychology|date=March 2010}} '''Remote therapy''', sometimes called '''telemental health applications'''{{cite journal |first1=David |last1=Hailey |first2=Risto |last2=Roine |first3=Arto |last3=Ohinmaa |title=The Effectiveness of Telemental Health Applications: A Review |journal=The Canadian Journal of Psychiatry |pmid=19087471 |url=http://publications.cpa-apc.org/media.php?mid=694&xwm=true |year=2008 |volume=53 |issue=11 |pages=769–78}} or '''Internet-based psychotherapy''',{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(09)61415-X |title=It's time for disruptive innovation in psychotherapy |year=2009 |last1=Simon |first1=Gregory E |last2=Ludman |first2=Evette J |journal=The Lancet |volume=374 |issue=9690 |pmid=19699995 |pages=594–5}} is a form of [[psychotherapy]] or related psychological practice in which a trained psychotherapist meets with a client or patient via telephone, cellular phone, the internet or other electronic media in place of or in addition to conventional [[Face-to-face (philosophy)|face-to-face]] psychotherapy. Initially, it was primarily intended a substitution for conventional, face-to-face therapy in which a client or patient is required to visit a psychotherapists office. Increasingly, however, academics are studying the use of electronic media in treatment to explore the possibility of providing novel and potentially more effective therapies. After reviewing thirteen relevant studies, the authors of a meta-analytic review of psychotherapy mediated by remote communications technology concluded that:
Remote therapy has the potential to overcome some of the barriers to conventional psychological therapy services. Telephone-based interventions are a particularly popular research focus and as a means of therapeutic communication may confer specific advantages in terms of their widespread availability and ease of operation. However, the available evidence is limited in quantity and quality. More rigorous trials are required to confirm these preliminary estimates of effectiveness.{{cite journal |doi=10.1186/1471-244X-8-60 |title=Psychotherapy mediated by remote communication technologies: A meta-analytic review |year=2008 |last1=Bee |first1=Penny E |last2=Bower |first2=Peter |last3=Lovell |first3=Karina |last4=Gilbody |first4=Simon |last5=Richards |first5=David |last6=Gask |first6=Linda |last7=Roach |first7=Pamela |journal=BMC Psychiatry |volume=8 |pages=60 |pmid=18647396 |pmc=2496903}}
== Examples == Despite the absence of complete study, remote therapy has enjoyed growing popularity as a replacement for traditional therapy and innovative practice made possible by electronic medium. Examples include: *The US Army has initiated a program in which soldiers in combat participate in video-based [[Couples counseling|relationship counseling]] with their partners at home.{{cite web|url=http://www.army.mil/-news/2009/06/15/22707-q-west-chaplains-introduce-video-teleconference-counseling-for-couples/|title=Q-West Chaplains Introduce Video Teleconference Counseling for Couples|publisher=WWW.ARMY.MIL (The Official Homepage of The United States Army)|accessdate=June 15, 2009|author=Sgt. 1st Class Adam Shaw}} *AbleTo {{cite web|url=http://ableto.com|title=AbleTo's offerings}} uses remote therapy to extend the reach of [[Empirically supported therapies|evidence-based practice]] and introduce innovative new practices, e.g., the team-based applications of [[cognitive behavioral therapy]] utilizing a licensed therapist and behavioral coach. *Mayo Clinic, provides remote cognitive rehabilitation sessions to patients who have had an acquired brain injury. Using an Internet-based, secure instant messaging platform, an office-based therapist conducts the rehabilitation session with the patient, who remains in or near his or her home.{{cite web|url=https://innovations.ahrq.gov/profiles/home-internet-enabled-therapy-sessions-enhance-access-cognitive-rehabilitation-traumatic|title=At-Home, Internet-Enabled Therapy Sessions Enhance Access to Cognitive Rehabilitation for Traumatic Brain Injury Patients, Leading to High Levels of Patient and Therapist Satisfaction}} ==See also== * [[Telemedicine]] == References == {{reflist}} {{Telemedicine navbox}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Remote Therapy}} [[Category:Telehealth]] [[Category:Telecommunication services]] [[Category:Health informatics]] [[Category:Assistive technology]]

[[File:Robotino with Hokuyo URG-04LX-UG01.jpg|thumb|Robotino equipped with a Hokuyo URG-04LX-UG01 rangefinder]] [[File:Robotino robview2 sdf.png|thumb|Robotino View 2 programming environment (sub program view).]] [[File:Robotino robview2 sfc.png|thumb|Robotino View 2 Programmierumgebung (main program view).]]
'''Robotino''' is a [[mobile robot|mobile robot system]] made by ''[[Festo]] Didactic'', and used for educational, training and research purposes.
==Operation== Robotino is based on an omnidirectional drive assembly, which enables the system to roam freely. The robot is controlled by an industry-standard PC system, which is powerful enough to plan routes for fully autonomous driving. Via a WLAN-Link, Robotino can send all sensor readings to an external PC. In the other direction, control commands can be issued by the external PC. This way, control programs can run on the external PC or on Robotino directly. Mixed mode or shared control are also possible.
For users with little prior robotics knowledge, Robotino can be readily programmed in its “native” programming environment RobotinoView II. More experienced programmers may find it useful that the robot can also be programmed in [[C_(programming_language)|C]], [[C++]], [[Java_programming|Java]], [[.NET Framework|.NET]], [[Matlab]], [[Simulink]], [[Labview]] and [[Microsoft Robotics Developer Studio]].
==Hardware== The omnidirectional drive consists of three [[Mecanum wheel]]s, all of which are individually controllable. These wheels are arranged at angles of 120°. Robotino has a bumper sensor around its circumference, infrared distance sensors, a color camera with VGA resolution, [[rotary encoder|optical wheel encoders]], power measurement for the entire system and the various motors, as well as a battery voltage monitor. Moreover, as optional additional sensors, Robotino can be equipped with a precise laser scanner, a gyroscope, and an [[indoor positioning system]] (created by [[Evolution Robotics]]). For signal input and output Robotino has several interfaces: * USB * Ethernet * 8 digital and 8 analog inputs * 8 digital outputs * additional motor output for driving high loads * additional encoder input
Power is supplied by two 12V/5Ah lead-acid batteries or optionally by two 12V/9Ah NiMH batteries.
== External links == {{Commons category}} * [http://www.festo-didactic.com/int-en/learning-systems/education-and-research-robots-robotino/ Robotino at Festo Didactic] * [http://wiki.openrobotino.org Robotino wiki] * [http://forum.openrobotino.org Robotino forum]

In the field of [[physical security]], '''security lighting''' is lighting that intended to deter or detect intrusions or other criminal activity on a piece of real property. It can also be used to increase a feeling of safety. Lighting is integral to [[crime prevention through environmental design]].
== Planning considerations == Security lighting can be counter-productive. Turning off lights halved the number of thefts and burglary in [[Övertorneå]] Sweden. <ref name="Clark"> [http://asv.org.au/light-pollution.php "Outdoor Lighting and Crime, Part 2"] by Barry Clark 2003, p. 18 and Figure 5 </ref><ref> "[[Svenska Dagbladet]]": [http://www.svd.se/nyheter/inrikes/artikel_206469.svd "Halverad brottslighet i mörk kommun"] (''Halved crime in the dark city.'') 2007 (''The number of thefts and burglaries have halved in Övertorneå since the city was dark in the fall because of the nationwide family dispute with Ekfors Kraft. We thought it would be the opposite, says Sören Mukkavaara, police constable in Övertorneå.'') </ref> A test in West Sussex UK showed that adding all-night lighting in some areas made people there feel safer, although crime rates increased 55% in those areas compared to control areas and to the county as a whole.<ref> [http://calgary.rasc.ca/lp/crime.html "Light and Crime"] </ref>
{{Cquote|In the early seventies, the public-school system in San Antonio, Texas, began leaving many of its school buildings, parking lots, and other property dark at night and found that the no-lights policy not only reduced energy costs but also dramatically cut vandalism.<ref>Schneier on Security [http://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2007/09/light_and_crime.html "Light and Crime"]</ref>}}
Bright, unshielded floodlights often prevent people from noticing criminal activity, and help criminals see what they are doing.<ref>[http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2007/08/20/070820fa_fact_owen?currentPage=2 "The Dark Side: Making war on light pollution"] by David Owen 2007</ref>
While adequate lighting around a physical structure is deployed to reduce the risk of an intrusion, it is critical that the lighting be designed carefully as poorly arranged lighting can create [[Light pollution#Glare|glare]] which actually obstructs vision. Studies {{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} have shown that many criminals are aware of this effect and actively exploit it. The optimal design will also depend on whether the area will be watched directly by humans or by [[closed-circuit television]], and on the location of the observers or cameras.
Security lighting may be subject to [[vandalism]], possibly to reduce its effectiveness for a subsequent intrusion attempt. Thus security lights should either be mounted very high, or else protected by [[wire]] [[mesh]] or tough [[polycarbonate]] shields. Other lamps may be completely recessed from view and access, with the light directed out through a [[light pipe]] or reflected from a polished aluminium or stainless steel [[mirror]]. For similar reasons high security installations may provide a [[Emergency power system|stand-by power supply]] for their security lighting.
Some typical considerations include:
* Reduce and prevent glare and situations mentioned above ** Shielded or full cut-off (FCO) lamp housings which conceal the bulb could be used, which should direct light onto the ground or target and away from observers. These lights should send no light above 80 degrees from the [[nadir]]. Lighting should be bright enough, and not "as bright as possible". In many cases a good [[rule of thumb]] is 0.5 [[watt]]s per square metre (0.05 watts per square foot). This might need to be increased in very confused environments, but conversely can be reduced in very open environments. Multiple lamps of moderate power instead of a few powerful lamps will reduce glare, provide more even illumination with reduced pools of shadow, and provide some redundancy if one lamp's bulb blows out or develops a bad ballast. * Prevent malicious tampering or interference. This means that besides the lamp itself, the entire circuit from the source ([[Electrical power industry|electric company]] or generator), through the wires, to the lamp and back should be protected. ** Luminaires should be accessible so that the maintainer can replace blown bulbs as quickly as possible and clean the luminaires periodically. However they should be protected or somehow made inaccessible to tampering. ** Ensure the [[electric meter]] box is locked or inaccessible, or else power the lights from a different line. ** Control and power lines, where outside or vulnerable, should be either buried well underground (in [[Electrical conduit|conduit]]s preferably) or at a height of at least 8 metres (about 24 feet). ** Ideally multiple circuits should be used to prevent an accidental or malicious short or cut causing all illumination to fail.
== Use == [[Image:Na-light.jpg|thumb|A sodium vapor light. This type is often used as security lighting.]] Security lighting can be used in residential, commercial, industrial, institutional, and military settings. Some examples of security lighting include [[High-intensity discharge lamp|floodlight]]s and [[sodium vapor lamp|low pressure sodium vapour light]]s. Most lights intended to be left on all night are [[high-intensity discharge lamp]]s as these have good energy efficiency, thus reducing the cost of running a lamp for such long periods.
A disadvantage of low pressure sodium lamps is that the colour is pure yellow, so the illuminated scene is seen without any colour differentiation. Consequently, high pressure sodium vapour lamps (which are still yellowish, but closer to golden white) are also used, at the cost of greater running expenses and increased light pollution. High pressure sodium lamps also take slightly longer to restrike after a power interruption.
Other lights may be activated by sensors such as [[passive infrared sensor]]s (PIRs), turning on only when a person (or other mammal) approaches. PIR activated lamps will usually be incandescent bulbs so that they can activate instantly; energy saving is less important since they will not be on all the time. PIR sensor activation can increase both the deterrent effect (since the intruder knows that he has been detected) and the detection effect (since a person will be attracted to the sudden increase in light). Some PIR units can be set up to sound a chime as well as turn on the light. Most modern units have a [[photocell]] so that they only turn on when it is dark.
== Limitations == An important limitation to the usefulness of security lighting is the simple fact that it is only useful at night. This is particularly significant for home owners because, contrary to a widespread myth, most household [[burglary|burglaries]] occur during the day,<ref name="Clark"/><ref>"Sourcebook of criminal justice statistics Online": [http://www.albany.edu/sourcebook/pdf/t31452007.pdf "Percent distribution of burglaries known to police. By place and time of occurrence, United States, 1976-2007"]</ref><ref>[http://www.britastro.org/dark-skies/crime.html "Lighting & Crime"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090603171645/http://www.britastro.org/dark-skies/crime.html |date=2009-06-03 }} from the [[British Astronomical Association]]'s [[Campaign for Dark Skies]]</ref> when the occupants are away at work or shopping.
As with any lighting, security lighting can reduce [[night vision]], making it harder to see into areas that are unlit or are in shadow.
== See also == * [[Access control]] * [[Environmental design]] * [[Light pollution]] * [[Physical Security]] * [[Security]] * [[Security engineering]]
== References == <references/>

'''Simon House''' is at 33 Daveys Bay Road, [[Mount Eliza, Victoria|Mount Eliza]] in [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]]. The house was constructed in the 1960s during the period of architectural experimentation on materiality and structure in houses. Simon House was the first project received on the day when [[Guilford Marsh Bell|Guilford Bell]] and [[Neil Clerehan]] opened their office in South Yarra. The Simons were Clerehan’s partners but the house was a collaboration of partners. Therefore, the house has a mixture of both Clerehan and Bell’s typical style of architecture.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Architecture of Neil Clerehan|year=2005|publisher=RMIT University Press|location=Melbourne|isbn=0-86459-383-X|pages=15|author=Black R& Edquist H}}</ref>
== Description == The house is a single-storey house, planned in a rectangular shape. The house consists of five bedrooms, two toilets, two garages, one kitchen, dining room, living room, pool and terrace. The enclosed pool, natural finishes, glazed wall and an extensive view over the bay recalled contemporary Californian house of architects like [[Craig Ellwood]].<ref>{{cite book|title=The Architecture of Neil Clerehan|year=2005|publisher=RMIT University Press|location=Melbourne|isbn=0-86459-383-X|pages=37–41|author=Black R& Edquist H}}</ref> [[File:Simon house diagram plan.jpg|thumb|design diagram]]
== Design Approach == The central core program of the house was a pool and terrace, positioned right in the centre of the house. With the pool and terrace in the centre with programs surrounds <ref>{{cite book|title=The Architecture of Neil Clerehan|year=2005|publisher=RMIT University Press|location=Melbourne|isbn=0-86459-383-X|pages=37–41|author=Black R& Edquist H}}</ref> that engaged with it, allows family members to gather together. It was said that was one of Clerehan’s conception of the house where how he deal with the provision of a frame for family life.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/money/profile-neil-clerehan/2006/08/07/1154802816814.html?page=2 | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | title=Profile: Neil Clerehan | date=9 August 2006}}</ref> The pool and living room aligned on axis, forming the central part of a symmetrical square plan. Then the programs around the pool were given a corresponding position in the house’s spatial hierarchy. Because of this distinct insistence of having an equivalent position of programs, the programs are mirrored and consist of dual garages and entrances. It was said that was one of Bell’s typical style of architecture.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Architecture of Neil Clerehan|year=2005|publisher=RMIT University Press|location=Melbourne|isbn=0-86459-383-X|pages=37–41|author=Black R& Edquist H}}</ref>
Bell has been influenced by the architecture and gardens of Japan. As a countryman, he feels, when in the city, a hunger for the freedom of sky and vegetation. He thinks that a building must stand in spectacular relationship to its environment.<ref>{{cite book|title=1952-1980 Architecture of Guilford Bell|year=1982|publisher=Proteus Publishing Pty. Ltd.|location=South Melbourne|isbn=0-949635-00-6|pages=7–9|author=Anne Imrie}}</ref> With the pool and terrace positioned in the centre of the house, the engagement between the indoor and outdoor spaces then became ambiguous. It creates a sense of feeling when one is inside, it will feels like outdoors and when one is outside it will feels like indoors. One of his design principal was that he thinks of views or views from the building first, instead of the form of the building.<ref>{{cite book|title=1952-1980 Architecture of Guilford Bell|year=1982|publisher=Proteus Publishing Pty. Ltd.|location=South Melbourne|isbn=0-949635-00-6|pages=7–9|author=Anne Imrie}}</ref> Therefore, glass panels are used across the living and dining areas to capture the view of the bay.[[File:Image of simon house.JPG|thumb|perspective view of outside terrace]]
== Current == Unfortunately, one of the garage have been renovated into a main entrance, also as a living room. Another garage is built right opposite the existing garage. In this approach, it loses the spatial qualities of the house but in turn allows a convenient use to the owner in the house’s circulation. [[File:Simon house current view.JPG|thumb|current view of Simon House garage]]
== Materiality == The materiality that uses in the house were unadorned, they are fibrous plaster ceiling left in natural, unpainted stated, flat steel decking roof, timber walls, and reinforced concrete floor slab under concrete block.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Architecture of Neil Clerehan|year=2005|publisher=RMIT University Press|location=Melbourne|isbn=0-86459-383-X|pages=37–41|author=Black R& Edquist H}}</ref>
== Awards == Neil Clerehan and Guilford Bell has received numerous honours for his architectural works while they were practicing architecture.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://users.tce.rmit.edu.au/E03159/ModMelb/mm2/modmelbprac2/nc/ncbio.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-11-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091001042824/http://users.tce.rmit.edu.au/e03159/ModMelb/mm2/modmelbprac2/nc/ncbio.html |archivedate=2009-10-01 |df= }}</ref> The Simon House was the most prominent work of Bell Clerehan partnership.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Architecture of Neil Clerehan|year=2005|publisher=RMIT University Press|location=Melbourne|isbn=0-86459-383-X|pages=37–41|author=Black R& Edquist H}}</ref> The home beautiful considered the pool, terrace to be one of Australia’s outstanding outdoor areas. The Simon house won the Victorian Architecture Medal in 1963-1964.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://users.tce.rmit.edu.au/E03159/ModMelb/mm2/modmelbprac2/nc/ncbio.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-11-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091001042824/http://users.tce.rmit.edu.au/e03159/ModMelb/mm2/modmelbprac2/nc/ncbio.html |archivedate=2009-10-01 |df= }}</ref>

The '''slicer,''' also called '''slicing software,''' is a [[computer software]] used in the majority of [[3D printing processes]] for the conversion of a 3D object model to specific instructions for the printer. In particular, the conversion from a model in [[STL (file format)|STL]] format to printer commands in [[g-code]] format in [[fused filament fabrication]] and other similar processes <ref>{{cite book |last=Evans|first=Brian |title=Practical 3D Printers: The Science and Art of 3D Printing|publisher=apress|isbn=978-1-4302-4393-9}}</ref> <ref>{{cite book |last=Keon Aristech Boozarjomehri|title=3D Printing at School and Makerspaces: Project Learning with 3D Printing|publisher=Cavendish Square|isbn=978-1-6804-5016-3}}</ref> <ref>{{cite book |last=Liza Wallach Kloski, Nick Kloski|title=Getting Started with 3D Printing: A Hands-on Guide to the Hardware, Software, and Services Behind the New Manufacturing Revolution|publisher=Maker Media, Inc|isbn=978-1-6804-5020-0}}</ref> <ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://reprap.org/wiki/Slicer|title=Slicer - RepRap|website=reprap.org|language=en|access-date=2018-09-15}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.goprint3d.co.uk/blog/what-is-slicing-software-and-what-does-it-do/|title=What is Slicing Software, and what does it do?|website=www.goprint3d.co.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-09-15}}</ref> .
The slicer first divides the object as a stack of flat layers, followed by describe these layers as linear movements of the 3D printer extruder, fixation laser or equivalent. All these movements, together with some specific printer commands like the ones to control the extruder temperature or bed temperature, are finally written in the g-code file, that can after be transferred to the printer.
== Additional features of the slicer ==
Near all slicers have some additional features, like:
[[File:Infill density.jpg|left|thumb|Different densities of infill (in yellow), as generated by [https://ultimaker.com/en/products/ultimaker-cura-software Cura] slicer, from solid to hollow.]] *'''Infill''': solid objects needs a big amount of valuable material (filament, ...) and print time. The slicer can automatically convert solid volumes to hollow ones, saving costs and time. The hollow object can be partially filled by internal structures, as internals walls, to provide additional robustness. The amount of these structures is called '''infill density''', being this parameter one of the adjustments to be provided to the slicer.
[[File:Support structure in 3D printing.jpg|thumb|Support structure (in blue) generated by [https://ultimaker.com/en/products/ultimaker-cura-software Cura] software. ]] *'''Supports''': most of the 3D printing processes create the object layer by layer, down to up, with the layer under construction being deposited over the previous one. As consequence, all object parts must relay, at least in some part, over another one. In the case of an object layer that is floating (by example, the flat roof of a house or an horizontally extended arm in a figure), the slicer automatically can add '''supports''' for it. The support touch the object in a way that is easily detachable from it at the finish stage of the object production.
[[File:Skirts, Brims, Rafts.jpg|thumb|Comparative of base layers (in blue): a) skirt; b) brim; c) raft, generated by [https://ultimaker.com/en/products/ultimaker-cura-software Cura] software]] * '''Rafts''', '''skirts''' and '''brims''': printing of the first object layer, the one in contact with the printer bed, has some peculiarities, like problems of object adherence to the bed, rugosity, smooth deposition of the first amounts of filament, ... <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://3dprinting.stackexchange.com/questions/65/when-should-i-use-a-raft-when-should-i-use-a-brim|title=When should I use a raft, when should I use a brim?|website=3D Printing Stack Exchange|access-date=2018-09-15}}</ref> . The slicer can automatically add some detachable structures to minimize these problems. Usual types of these base structures are <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.simplify3d.com/support/articles/rafts-skirts-and-brims/|title=Rafts, Skirts and Brims!|website=www.simplify3d.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-15}}</ref> a '''skirt''' (a single band around the base of the object without touching it), a '''brim''' (several lines of filament around the base of the object, each one a few more far from it until touch it, but not under it) and '''rafts''' (several layers of material that forms a detachable base, being the object printed over it).
== List of slicer software ==
It exists a wide collection of slicer applications, some of them [[Free and open-source software|free and open-source]]. Some of the most used ones are <ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://all3dp.com/1/best-3d-slicer-software-3d-printer/|title=Best 3D Slicer Software for 3D Printers of 2018 (Most are Free) {{!}} All3DP|date=2018-06-01|work=All3DP|access-date=2018-09-15|language=en-US}}</ref>:
- [[Cura (software)|Ultimaker Cura]]
- [https://www.simplify3d.com/ Simplify3D]
- [[Slic3r]]
- [http://www.kisslicer.com/ KISSlicer]

{{Infobox company | name = South Carolina Hydrogen & Fuel Cell Alliance | logo = | type = Non-Profit | foundation = 2006 | location_city = [[Columbia, S.C.]] | location_country = [[United States]] | key_people = [[Shannon Baxter-Clemmons]], Executive Director | homepage = http://www.schydrogen.org }}
The '''South Carolina Hydrogen & Fuel Cell Alliance (SCHFCA)''' is a Public-private collaborative with a mission of advancing the commercialization of hydrogen [[fuel cell]] technologies in the state of [[South Carolina]].<ref>http://www.sc.edu/hydrogen/news_resources.php</ref> Government entities, in particular, the Department of Energy has funded SCHFCA with $188,788 for a hydrogen education program for state and local officials.<ref>http://www.energy.sc.gov/news.aspx?id=97</ref> State taxpayers have already chipped in $12.3 million for hydrogen fuel cell development, while other non-state entities like federal and private sources have invested nearly $115 million into the development of the technology.<ref>http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G1-206569280.html</ref>
== Founding organizations == SCHFCA was founded in 2006 by six core institutions that were devoted to Hydrogen & Fuel Cell initiatives and development. *[[University of South Carolina]] *[[Clemson University]] *Applied Research Center: Hydrogen *[[Savannah River National Laboratory]] *The South Carolina Department of Commerce *[[South Carolina State University]].
== Affiliate members == *SCRA *South Carolina Energy Office *[[EngenuitySC]] *Greenway Energy LLC *South Carolina Fire Marshal's Office *NSF Industry/University Cooperative Research Center for Fuel Cells *Palmetto State Clean Fuel Coalition *[[South Carolina Technical College System]]
== See also == *[[National Hydrogen Association]] *[[United States Department of Energy]] *[[Savannah River Site]]
